author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Victor J. Blue, Jim Huylebroek and Christina Goldbaum
title: ‘I Never Believed That Would Happen’: After 20 Years of War, an Abrupt End
description: Amid the uncertainty that lies ahead under a Taliban-controlled government, Afghans reflect on the final months of fighting.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — By the time Ghulam Maroof Rashid’s 50th birthday passed, he had spent more than one-third of his life fighting for the Taliban on one battlefield or another in Afghanistan. He believed they would eventually win the war but had no idea that this year would finally be its end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Fincke
title: Passing the Time With a Piano-Playing Pilot
description: As a pilot with United Airlines, Beau Brant flies North American routes. At every layover, he looks to play a mix of jazz, classical and more for his crew and strangers.
content: It’s after midnight at the Palm Court in Cincinnati and staff is trying to close. Lights are dimmed as the last of the martini glasses and beer bottles are scooped up. But Beau Brant is still at the piano, playing for stragglers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: As Johnson Draws a Happy Face, Britons Confront a Run of Bad News
description: There’s a cognitive dissonance between Mr. Johnson’s upbeat appraisal of British life and the ills facing its citizens, including gas and food shortages and fears of rising energy prices.
content: LONDON — Britons are lining up for gas, staring at empty grocery shelves, paying higher taxes and worrying about spiraling prices as a grim winter approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: The College Admissions Scandal: Where Some of the Defendants Are Now
description: Dozens of parents and others have pleaded guilty. Here’s what happened to a few of them.
content: The first two people to stand trial in the college admissions bribery scandal were found guilty on Friday. But the two defendants, Gamal Abdelaziz, a former casino executive, and John Wilson, a private equity investor, both parents, joined a list of dozens of figures who have received judgments through plea agreements in the case that federal investigators call Operation Varsity Blues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Fernandez Moves On and Raducanu Returns to Tennis Reality at Indian Wells
description: The teenagers who stunned and delighted fans on their way to the U.S. Open final in September returned to compete at the BNP Paribas Open as headliners.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Nearly a month after Emma Raducanu and Leylah Fernandez faced off in perhaps the most unexpected Grand Slam singles final, they returned to action as headliners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Deontay Wilder and Tyson Fury: A Trilogy Defined by Its Twists
description: The pandemic, bureaucratic bickering and genuine dislike feed into this third showdown for a heavyweight belt.
content: LAS VEGAS — For more than 30 minutes, the two combatants talked relatively calmly to each other as the room became thick with tension as each man nonchalantly described what violence he would unleash on the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Furman
title: A Portrait Inspired by the Bright Colors of Los Angeles
description: For one of the works in his new solo show, the painter Amoako Boafo drew on the sunny shades that surrounded him in the lead-up to the opening.
content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a piece by the painter Amoako Boafo that appears in his solo exhibition “Singular Duality: Me Can Make We,” on view at Roberts Projects in Los Angeles through November 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon put us on unsteady ground.
content: ACROSTIC — I absolutely inched through this puzzle, and I find a majority of the entry difficult, even in hindsight. My theory is that this was intentional on the part of our constructors, to give us a challenging puzzle about a challenging topic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Candidate for ‘Mayah’ Proudly Leans Into Her Boston Sound
description: The mayoral candidate Annissa Essaibi George, the daughter of Polish and Tunisian immigrants, speaks with the accent of working-class Boston. And she’s having some fun with it.
content: BOSTON — The mayoral candidate Annissa Essaibi George was amping up her supporters, who had gathered in an Italian restaurant on the waterfront, a little punchy after a long day of getting out the vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Katherine Rosman
title: The Real Trials of a ‘Real Housewife’
description: Erika Girardi is famous for her lavish lifestyle. Now her husband’s law firm has been accused of misappropriating millions of dollars. It’s all unfolding on TV.
content: From a bit part as a dead body on “Law & Order” to six seasons on “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills,” television has been a crucial part of Erika Girardi’s careful cultivation of her branded glamorous life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: The Team Heard Round the World
description: The nationalization of sports tells a tale of American politics too.
content: I once watched a Cincinnati Bengals wild-card matchup on my phone in Auckland, New Zealand. It was a terrible idea. Not because of my phone or the huge time difference, but because my team managed to fall apart in an apocalyptically terrible fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Journalists in Philippines and Russia Are Cited for Courage
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 9, 2021.
content: “The fight against the media is not a fight against the media. It is a fight against the people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Facing Criminal Inquiry, Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz Resigns
description: After insisting he would remain in office amid accusations that public money was used to produce favorable polling, Mr. Kurz said he would step aside to resolve a government crisis.
content: BERLIN — Chancellor Sebastian Kurz of Austria announced on Saturday that he would resign, days after prosecutors began a criminal investigation into allegations he used public money to pay off pollsters and journalists for favorable coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell and Oskar Garcia
title: Here’s how to watch and stream the Wilder-Fury fight.
description: The main event will likely happen sometime after 11 p.m. Eastern.
content: The heavyweight title fight between Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder will be televised on both Fox Sports’ and ESPN’s pay-per-view platforms in the United States, with a price of $79.99. The pay-per-view card begins at 9 p.m. Eastern on Saturday. And yes, it’s a bit unusual to have two big sports networks carry the same event, though that’s one of the quirks sometimes present in boxing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The Zambian Economist at the Crossroads of Global Business
description: Dambisa Moyo has the ear of top business leaders. But there are no simple answers to complex problems.
content: For policymakers and business leaders seeking simple answers to complex problems, Dambisa Moyo is a valuable sounding board. With a Ph.D. in economics from Oxford, a master of public administration from Harvard and experience serving on the boards of companies like Chevron, 3M and Barclays, Ms. Moyo has the kind of broad exposure and macroeconomic knowledge that is often lacking in the upper reaches of siloed organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With Textbook Win, the Astros Take a Commanding Series Lead
description: Dazzling defense kept Game 2 close and a huge seventh inning powered Houston to victory. After cruising all season, the White Sox are on the brink of elimination.
content: HOUSTON — If you kept score at Minute Maid Park on Friday, you might have felt like a grade-school teacher with a class full of honor students, scribbling little stars onto paper all day. The Houston Astros’ defense was just that dazzling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Precious Fondren
title: Passenger’s ‘Erratic Behavior’ Draws Emergency Response at La Guardia
description: A flight from Indianapolis declared an emergency and landed after a passenger acted suspiciously, officials said.
content: Firefighters and police personnel converged on a plane that had traveled from Indianapolis and landed at La Guardia Airport on Saturday afternoon after a “security incident,” according to a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian and Sarah Kessler
title: Michael Dell Is Trying to Be Nice
description: In “Play Nice But Win,” Mr. Dell delves into the drama behind some of the biggest deals of the past decade.
content: Books about deal making are the thrillers of the business world. There is conflict. There are high stakes. There is bluffing, bragging and bullying. There are “Barbarians at the Gate.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: A Language Bill Deepens a Culture Clash in Quebec
description: The government calls the new measure necessary for the survival of French, while critics say it stigmatizes bilingualism and is bad for business.
content: MONTREAL — Since Aude Le Dubé opened an English-only bookshop in Montreal last year, she has had several unwelcome guests each month: Irate Francophones, sometimes draped in Quebec flags, who storm in and berate her for not selling books in French.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: A Delta-driven surge is pushing hospitals in North Dakota to the brink.
description: “The pressure on hospitals and clinics in both our urban and rural areas is reaching critical levels,” Gov. Doug Burgum said last week.
content: While the Delta variant-driven surge is receding in much of the United States, it rages on in less-vaccinated states like North Dakota,  to the point where the state’s governor and health professionals have asked people to avoid risky activities that could add to the burden on hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Most Abortions in Texas Are Banned Again After Court Ruling
description: A federal appeals court panel temporarily reinstated the law that bans most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy while it considers a district judge’s ruling.
content: HOUSTON — A federal appeals court panel reinstated Texas’ restrictive abortion law late Friday, temporarily restoring a ban on virtually all procedures that had been blocked by a lower court two days earlier in a case brought by the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
title: ‘Starting a Fire’: U.S. and China Enter Dangerous Territory Over Taiwan
description: The self-ruled island has moved to the heart of deepening discord and rivalry between the two superpowers, with the potential to ignite military conflagration and reshape the regional order.
content: The 25 Chinese fighter jets, bombers and other warplanes flew in menacing formations off the southern end of Taiwan, a show of military might on China’s National Day, Oct. 1. The incursions, dozens upon dozens, continued into the night and the days that followed and surged to the highest numbers ever on Monday, when 56 warplanes tested Taiwan’s beleaguered air defenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Lifestyles of the Rich and Gullible: Theranos and Ozy Edition
description: Average investors were not able to get in on the last decade’s start-up boom in private markets. Once that seemed unfair. Now it looks lucky.
content: Ozy Media told investors it had “strong financial performance, seemingly impressive viewership metrics and significant institutional investor interest,” according to a firm that heard the pitch. In return, it got $2 million in funding, adding to its $83 million haul. Last week, that firm sued, alleging fraud and concealment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kravitz Hoeffner
title: Back in Lesbian Paradise, at Long Last
description: The Dinah Shore Weekend, an annual festival for queer women, returned to Palm Springs last weekend after a two-year hiatus, this time with even more energy than usual.
content: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — In late September, when thousands of people descended on the Hilton Palm Springs for a marathon weekend of pool parties, concerts and club nights, it had been close to 19 months since Covid-19 put life as we knew it on pause — not to mention, more than two years since this desert city had been transformed into a lively lesbian oasis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Chicago’s mayor guts the city’s vaccine mandate for public workers.
description: A day after President Biden visited to issue a national plea for more vaccine mandates, Mayor Lori Lightfoot said Chicago’s public workers could opt out of the city’s until the end of the year by getting regularly tested.
content: Just a day after President Biden visited Chicago to plead for vaccine mandates, saying they were the only way to defeat the coronavirus, Mayor Lori Lightfoot on Friday said public workers could opt out of the city’s mandate until the end of the year by getting regularly tested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Serial Killer Gets 160 Years After Victim’s Sister and Friends Help Solve Case
description: Khalil Wheeler-Weaver, 25, a former security guard from Orange, N.J., was sentenced for murdering three women and kidnapping and attempting to murder a fourth.
content: When Sarah Butler did not return to her home in Montclair, N.J., after borrowing her mother’s minivan in November 2016, her family immediately recognized that she might be in trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Red Sox Prove ‘Hitting Is Contagious’ in Series-Tying Win
description: Tampa Bay got off to a hot start, but Boston’s offense was relentless in what turned into a five-homer blowout.
content: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Boston Red Sox are an imperfect team. They made the second most fielding errors in the major leagues during the regular season. Their pitching staff ranked, depending on the statistic, in the top third or middle of the pack. But make no mistake, they can absolutely crush the ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: ‘A Safe Space’: Black Pastors Promote Vaccinations from the Pulpit
description: More than 80 percent of adults in New York City have received at least one dose of the coronavirus vaccine, but there are significant racial disparities in the vaccination rate.
content: Dozens of people gathered at the Word of Life International Church in the South Bronx on a recent Saturday for its weekly food bank, but the pastor wanted to ask the crowd a question before the groceries were handed out: Did anyone know where to find the closest vaccination site?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Lawmakers See Path to Rein In Tech, but It Isn’t Smooth
description: If what faces Big Tech is anything like what happened to Big Tobacco, the road ahead is likely to be a yearslong battle over proposed rules and regulations.
content: WASHINGTON — “Facebook and Big Tech are facing a Big Tobacco moment,” Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, said this week when a whistle-blower testified about how the social media company’s products harmed teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Gen. Raymond T. Odierno Dies at 67; Oversaw Iraq Surge
description: The four-star general helped carry out the strategy to increase U.S. troop numbers, which was credited with turning the tide of sectarian killings.
content: Raymond T. Odierno, a four-star Army general who was an influential architect of the surge of American forces during the Iraq war that helped quell sectarian killings and increase stability in the country, died on Friday. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can My Landlord Put Locks in My Apartment That I Can’t Open?
description: Sometimes landlords have to be reminded that they cannot create unsafe living conditions for their tenants.
content: Q: I am renting a condo in a large Manhattan building. The bedrooms and one of the closets have deadbolt locks that can only be locked or unlocked with a key from the outside. The landlord will not give us keys to the locks. This seems like a serious safety issue, especially if there are children living in the apartment. Are these types of locks allowed on bedroom doors? If so, is the landlord required to provide us with a key to each lock? She has also suggested that if we want these locks removed, we will have to pay for that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canadian Admits Fabricating Terrorism Tale Detailed in New York Times Podcast
description: In exchange for the admission of the man, Shehroze Chaudhry, Canada dropped criminal charges against him.
content: OTTAWA — A Canadian man admitted in court on Friday that he made up tales about serving as an Islamic State fighter and executioner in Syria. In exchange, Canadian authorities dropped criminal charges against him of perpetrating a hoax involving the threat of terrorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: At Rwanda’s Favorite Bars, Forget the Beer: Milk Is What’s on Tap
description: Milk is a favorite drink in Rwanda, and milk bars serve it up in abundance, fresh or fermented, hot or cold. “When you drink milk, you always have your head straight and your ideas right.”
content: KIGALI, Rwanda — As the sun scorched the hilly Rwandan capital on a recent afternoon, a motorcycle taxi driver, two women in matching head scarves and a teenager wearing headphones all separately sauntered into a small roadside kiosk to drink the only thing on tap: milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Moshe Tendler, Authority on Jewish Medical Ethics, Dies at 95
description: His pronouncements — on sex, death, organ transplants and more — carried weight in no small part because he was both a master of Jewish scripture and a microbiologist.
content: One of the stories that recalls Rabbi Moshe Tendler’s charming candor starts out like a timeworn Jewish joke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: Her Hyper-Realistic Art Is a Parallel Universe
description: Ariana Papademetropoulos makes large-scale, iridescent works that transport viewers into alien worlds.
content: Name: Ariana Papademetropoulos
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Stop the Debt Ceiling Nonsense
description: In the fight over the debt ceiling, both political parties are behaving badly, albeit in very different ways.
content: In finally reaching an agreement this week to raise the federal debt ceiling, ensuring that the United States can pay its bills for the next few months, the members of the U.S. Senate have performed a public service roughly akin to that of a would-be arsonist who pockets the matchbook and walks away from the straw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Bill Clinton, Race and the Politics of the 1990s
description: What does “popularism” look like in practice?
content: My colleague Ezra Klein wrote his latest column on the work of David Shor, a Democratic polling analyst whose primary message is a critique of the Democratic Party, namely that its college-educated professional class is too removed from the working-class, non-college-educated voters they need to win. Here’s Ezra with a little more detail:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Tamir Kalifa
title: For Seasoned Soccer Travelers, No Other Trip Qualifies
description: Hitting the road for a World Cup qualifier might be one of the most unsung fan experiences in U.S. sports. Expansion of the tournament might change it forever.
content: One of the essential, and unsung, experiences in American sports fandom requires you to leave American soil altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: 52 Years in 11 Days: A Son, Facing Death, Finds His Father
description: After struggling with cancer for years, Sam Anthony was running out of time. Before he died, he found the courage to mail a letter that he had long been afraid to send.
content: FALLS CHURCH, Va. — Three weeks before he died, Sam Anthony, 52, mailed his last wishes to a man he had never met.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flávia Milhorance
title: Brazil’s Covid-19 death toll passes 600,000.
description: The figure represents a heartbreaking amount of loss, though at the same time, it was a signal that the rate of fatalities in the country has been slowing.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil surpassed the grim landmark of more than 600,000 Covid-19 deaths this week, making its death toll second only to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Vaccine hesitancy, an issue among police officers, is also evident among firefighters.
description: Hundreds of firefighters in Los Angeles have filed a notice of intent to sue to fight a vaccine mandate, with the threat of seeking more than $2.1 billion.
content: Vaccine hesitancy among police officers in the United States has been one of the themes of pandemic news this year, but in some places, firefighters are joining the resistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Moderna, Racing for Profits, Keeps Covid Vaccine Out of Reach of Poor
description: Some poorer countries are paying more and waiting longer for the company’s vaccine than the wealthy — if they have access at all.
content: Moderna, whose coronavirus vaccine appears to be the world’s best defense against Covid-19, has been supplying its shots almost exclusively to wealthy nations, keeping poorer countries waiting and earning billions in profit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Bolshoi Performer Is Killed in Onstage Accident
description: The man, in his late 30s, was crushed during a scene change as the opera “Sadko” was performed before an audience, the theater said.
content: A performer was killed during an opera at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow on Saturday when there was an accident during a scene change, the theater said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Debate Looms Over I.M.F.: Should It Do More Than Put Out Fires?
description: As the International Monetary Fund gets set for its annual meeting, economists ask if it’s time to update its mandate as the world’s financial crisis responder.
content: Lopsided access to vaccinations, extreme economic inequality, rising food prices and staggering debt are on the agenda when the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank gather for their annual meetings in Washington next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Kinzer
title: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, Former Iranian President, Dies at 88
description: He tried to resist the currents of Islamic radicalism, but was forced out of office when he lost the support of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
content: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who as the first president of the Islamic Republic of Iran tried and failed to resist the currents of religious radicalism, died on Saturday at the Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital in Paris. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: About 86 percent of home health aides in New York have met a deadline to be vaccinated.
description: But preliminary state data also show that at least 34,000 home health aides appeared to have missed the deadline, rendering them unable to work and worsening a labor shortage in the industry.
content: The vaccination rate among home health workers in New York as a deadline arrived on Thursday for them to get Covid shots was about 86 percent, exceeding the expectations of some union and industry leaders and suggesting thousands may have made a last-minute decision to be inoculated, according to preliminary state data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: When Child Care Costs Twice as Much as the Mortgage
description: President Biden’s social policy legislation aims to address a problem that weighs on many families — and the teachers and child care centers serving them.
content: GREENSBORO, N.C. — To understand the problems Democrats hope to solve with their supersized plan to make child care better and more affordable, consider this small Southern city where many parents spend more for care than they do for mortgages, yet teachers get paid like fast food workers and centers cannot hire enough staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Philippines’ Nobel Prize Newsroom Is Overjoyed but Under Siege
description: Rappler, the news site co-founded by the new Nobel laureate Maria Ressa, dares to criticize the Philippine president, Rodrigo Duterte. He may yet see it shut down.
content: The young editors and reporters of the Philippine news site Rappler were already busy on Friday. It was the last day candidates could file to run in next year’s elections, and the journalists were watching to see who would try to replace Rodrigo Duterte, the president who for years has attacked Rappler and threatened its staff members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Populist Leader of Czech Republic Narrowly Defeated in Election
description: The results suggest that the populist wave in Eastern and Central Europe is receding, stalled by the growing unity of its opponents and a crisis of confidence after the defeat of the former U.S. president.
content: PRAGUE — In a blow to Europe’s once surging populist politicians, the prime minister of the Czech Republic, a pugnacious businessman who has compared himself to Donald Trump and railed against migrants, suffered a surprising defeat in a parliamentary election that ended on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Joe Manchin’s Choices on Family Policy
description: How the conservative Democrat should be negotiating with his party.
content: There is an interesting counterfactual scenario for the now-flailing Biden presidency, where the president responded to the initial success of his bipartisan infrastructure push — all those Republicans at the White House, signing up for billions in new spending — by immediately going out and saying, let’s do the same for family policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: First, Impressive Vaccines for Covid. Next Up: The Flu.
description: Vaccine makers are betting that the mRNA technology powering two successful Covid vaccines will help curb the tragic global death toll from the flu.
content: As the world grapples with Covid-19, influenza isn’t getting much attention these days. But the flu’s global impact is staggering: three million to five million cases of severe illness every year, and up to 650,000 deaths. Every few decades, a new flu strain spills over from animals and leads to a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man Who Faked Suicide to Avoid Covid-19 Fraud Charges Is Sentenced
description: Prosecutors said David A. Staveley, who cut off his electronic monitoring bracelet and left suicide notes with friends and relatives, was sentenced to 56 months in prison.
content: Three weeks after he had been charged with trying to fraudulently obtain Covid-19 relief loans, David A. Staveley escaped by faking his own suicide, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Shades of Another Giants Era: A Youngster Tames the Dodgers
description: Logan Webb earned a comparison to a San Francisco legend by holding Los Angeles scoreless and striking out 10 batters.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When the San Francisco Giants won three World Series titles over the five-year period from 2010-14, they did so with young pitchers blossoming at just the right time. Without Tim Lincecum, Matt Cain and Madison Bumgarner, the Giants would not have risen to such heights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Months Before Oil Spill, Pipeline May Have Taken Quiet Damage
description: It’s likely that a large vessel’s anchor hit the pipeline, off the coast of Orange County, at some point up to a year ago, the U.S. Coast Guard said.
content: The pipeline that spilled at least 126,000 gallons of oil into the Pacific Ocean off the California coast may have been damaged up to a year earlier, according to preliminary results of an ongoing investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: More Than Discouraged
description: This debut puzzle by August Lee-Kovach is so good, it ought to be a felony.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — August Lee-Kovach is the 70th crossword constructor to make a Times debut so far this year. That’s a lot of new voices, which is a great harbinger of puzzles to come. (It’s also nice that several of those newbies have made two or more 2021 grids and begun to feel like regulars.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Trouble Comes for Big Tech
description: Will the industry finally have its feet held to the fire?
content: Could Jonathan Kanter have better timing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: ‘Clue’: The Movie
description: Brandon Koppy reels us into a cinematic Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is one of those sliced-bread themes that makes you wonder why nobody thought of it before, the mark of a great invention. We get movie puzzles (which are always fun) and we get a mystery every so often (please, if you missed it, solve “McGuffin Manor” next). But it took Brandon Koppy to make the connection that makes this puzzle’s theme, as far as I know, so I give him applause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: 6 Marathons in 6 Weeks? Shalane Flanagan Has 4 More to Go, and 2 This Weekend.
description: In her quest to run all six major marathons in this closely packed fall season, Flanagan will run Chicago on Sunday and Boston on Monday.
content: With the world’s six major marathons — Berlin, London, Chicago, Boston, Tokyo and New York City — squeezed into a six-week window this fall, most top runners had a tough decision to make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: In Candid Photos, Shannen Doherty Shows the Ravages of Breast Cancer
description: The actress, 50, who has Stage 4 cancer, said she posted the photos to help raise awareness about breast cancer prevention.
content: One picture shows the actress Shannen Doherty completely bald, a bloody cotton ball in her nose as she stares straight at the camera, looking almost confrontational.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Supreme Court v. Reality
description: These justices are courting disaster for the rest of us.
content: WASHINGTON — Ordinarily staid and silent Supreme Court justices have become whirling dervishes of late, spinning madly to rebut the idea that Americans are beginning to regard the court as a dangerous cabal of partisan hacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: Paradise Was Lost. She’s Telling Its Stories.
description: Lizzie Johnson talks about the reporting that went into her book “Paradise,” an account of the Camp Fire that ravaged California in 2018.
content: Images of the wildfire that devastated Paradise, Calif., in 2018 are hard to forget. Known as the Camp Fire — after Camp Creek Road, where it started — the disaster killed at least 85 people and essentially destroyed the entire town. Lizzie Johnson was a reporter at The San Francisco Chronicle at the time, and her new book, “Paradise,” is a vivid ticktock account of the disaster, told through the stories of those who experienced it. Johnson, now a reporter at The Washington Post, talks about the fire as a turning point, how the scope and structure of her book changed over time and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Why I’m Ending My ‘Wealth Matters’ Column
description: After 13 years, 608 installments, and an estimated 4,864 sources, I’m stepping away from my weekly column to explore the world of my other full-time job — lead dad.
content: When I told the deputy business editor a few months ago that I wanted to end my weekly “Wealth Matters” column we agreed on this weekend. I said it would be No. 608. He joked that might qualify me for the Hall of Fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: In Debate Over Conquistadors 500 Years Ago, Spanish Right Sees an Opportunity
description: Spanish politicians sparred with Pope Francis over their country’s role in conquering the Americas, signaling a nationalist tilt in the conservative establishment.
content: MADRID — In a letter to Mexican bishops last month, Pope Francis called for a revisiting of the country’s history, especially the role of the Roman Catholic Church, and urged clergy members to “recognize the painful errors committed in the past.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 9, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 9, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about the new malaria vaccine in Africa referred incorrectly to malaria in one instance. It is caused by a parasite, not a virus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gender-Neutral Pronouns: The Singular ‘They’ and Alternatives
description: Some readers find the new usage of “they” confusing and offer other options such as “que” and “s/he.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
